description:
Ascidiimonas meishanensis is a species of bacteria that was isolated from the sediment of the Meishan wetland in China. It belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes and the genus Ascidiimonas.

The cells of Ascidiimonas meishanensis are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and non-motile. They are typically rod-shaped and have a size range of 0.4-0.6 μm in width and 1.2-2.0 μm in length.

Ascidiimonas meishanensis is an aerobic bacterium, meaning it requires oxygen for growth and metabolism. It is chemoorganotrophic, which means it obtains its energy and carbon from organic compounds.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Ascidiimonas meishanensis is closely related to other members of the genus Ascidiimonas, which are commonly found in marine and freshwater environments.

The optimal growth conditions for Ascidiimonas meishanensis include a temperature range of 25-37°C and a pH range of 6.5-8.0. It is able to utilize a variety of carbohydrates, amino acids, and organic acids as carbon and energy sources.

This bacterial species has been studied for its potential role in wetland ecosystems and its potential applications in biotechnology, but further research is needed to fully understand its ecological and functional significance.
